qas.question: What was often used to hide functional parts of buildings?
What was occasionally visible in grander buildings?
What often topped pilasters of columns?
What designs did ornament use to avoid using the human figure?
What aspect of buildings became very rare?
What was often used too accentuate functional parts of buildings?
What type of courtyard became more popular at this time
What was typically visible from the ground?
What type of ornament was popular outside but not inside?
What was the human figure often used for?

context: <a4_0><b6_0>Internal courtyards<b6_0/><a4_0/> became more rare, except beside the stables, and the functional parts of the building were placed at the sides, or in separate buildings nearby hidden by <a0_0><b5_0>trees<b5_0/><a0_0/>. The views to and from the front and rear of the main block were concentrated on, with the side approaches usually much less important. <b7_0>The roof<b7_0/> was typically invisible from the ground, though <a1_0>domes<a1_0/> were sometimes visible in grander buildings. The roofline was generally clear of ornament except for a balustrade or the top of a pediment. <b8_0>Columns or pilasters,<b8_0/> often topped by a <a2_0>pediment<a2_0/>, were popular for ornament inside and out, and other <b9_0>ornament<b9_0/> was generally <a3_0>geometrical or plant-based<a3_0/>, rather than using the human figure.
